column4: I know this has been asked a million times, but I've got 450GB on this drive to play around with, and I want a sensible partition scheme that'll allow me to maximum flexibility.
what do you plan to do with the space?
store a metric butt-ton of legally obtained movies, music and tv shows. might end up installing apache and hosting a website

I would just create one huge partition for everything.  This, of course, assuming your OS drive is already taken care of; You could in theory mess around with LVMs, but since its one physical drive LVM would not convey any benefit
last time i made it one giant partition, and I wanted to upgrade my OS, I couldn't do that without saving and reinstalling everything, because my /home was in the same partition as root
i'd been told that /home /var and i think /usr should be in separate partitions if you have the room
and veracity to that recollection? would it do anything for me
ahhh so you want to put the os on the same disk?  hmm.
i had assumed that was standard procedure. Is it "bad form" to put the OS on the same disk?
that's how the standard installs come. actually, i'm not even sure how to set it up otherwise
I think your'e okay doing that.
so you still say leave it as one big partition? How about this inveratulo, if I *was* gonna break out specific first level directories, what ought they be? and any hints on relative sizes?
for servers i like to start out with /root, /boot, and a swap partition.  10gb for each
/home, /var, /opt are also worth looking into, depending on the application
villa1, sorry 10gb for /root not for the other two
i think the idea is to keep them small and don't part them out until it becomes neccessary, but then again if disk is not an issue just go crazy
